Covid-19 in Italy

Kexin Xu
08-25-2021

Contents

  • Data description
  • Data exploration

  • Refenrence

Introduction

According to the latest statistics released by the Italian Ministry of Health on August 29, there were 5,959 new COVID-19 cases in Italy in 24 hours, bringing the total number of confirmed COVID-19 cases to 4,530,246. A total of 37 new deaths were reported, with 129,093 deaths in total. These are numbers written on the paper but represent peoples health and even life! Lets now dig into those numbers and look through cases and deaths over the last two years.

Show code 
#coronavirus <- readRDS("coronavirus.rds")
map <- coronavirus %>% 
  group_by(country, type) %>%
  summarise(cases = sum(cases)) %>%
  left_join(map_data("world"), by = c("country" = "region")) %>%
  filter(type == "confirmed") %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = long, 
             y = lat, 
             group = group,
             text = country)) +
  geom_polygon(aes(fill = cases), 
               colour = "gray50") +
  scale_fill_continuous(type = "viridis") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(-180, 210, 45)) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(-60, 100, 30)) +
  labs(x = "Longitude", 
       y = "Latitude") +
  theme_light()

ggplotly(map)

Data description

Data is sourced from WHO Coronavirus (COVID-19) Dashboard. It is a worldwide data related to Coronavirus situation from the beginning of 2020 till now and only data of Italy is selected here. Variables and types are as follow.

Show code 
Italytable <- tribble(
  ~Variable, ~Type, ~Description,
  "Date_reported", "date", "The date reported",
  "Country_code", "character", "Counrty code",
  "Country", "character", "Country name",
  "WHO_region", "character", "Region of country in WHO",
  "New_cases", "double", "Daily new cases",
  "Cumulative_cases", "double", "Cumulative cases",
  "New_deaths", "double", "Daily new deaths",
  "Cumulative_deaths", "double", "Cumulative deaths"
) %>%
  as.data.frame()
kable(Italytable) %>%
  kable_styling("striped", position = 'center')
Variable Type Description
Date_reported date The date reported
Country_code character Counrty code
Country character Country name
WHO_region character Region of country in WHO
New_cases double Daily new cases
Cumulative_cases double Cumulative cases
New_deaths double Daily new deaths
Cumulative_deaths double Cumulative deaths
Show code 
WHO_COVID_19_global_data <- read_csv(here::here("_posts/post1/WHO-COVID-19-global-data.csv"))
Italy <- WHO_COVID_19_global_data %>%
  filter(Country == "Italy")

Data exploration

Show code 
Italy <- Italy %>%
  select(-c(Country_code, Country, WHO_region))
DT::datatable(Italy, 
              options = list(pageLength = 10), 
              caption = "Cases & Deaths in Italy from 2020 to the present")

Surprisingly, when sorted by New_cases or New_deaths in ascending order, you may find that there are 2 negative numbers which seem unreasonable. Why is this?
After checking the WHO Dashboard we can find: due to the trend of countries conducting data reconciliation exercises which remove large numbers of cases or deaths from their total counts, such data may reflect as negative numbers in the new cases / new deaths counts as appropriate.

Show code 
Cases <- Italy %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Date_reported)) +
  geom_area(aes(y = Cumulative_cases), fill = "lavender") +
  xlab("") +
  ylab("Cumulative Cases") +
  theme_bw() +
  scale_x_date(breaks = "82 days") +
  transition_reveal(Date_reported)

Deaths <- Italy %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Date_reported)) +
  geom_area(aes(y = Cumulative_deaths), fill = "lightcyan") +
  xlab("") +
  ylab("Cumulative Deaths") +
  theme_bw() +
  scale_x_date(breaks = "82 days") +
  transition_reveal(Date_reported)

Cases
Show code 
Deaths

Show code 
start_date <- min(Italy$Date_reported)
end_date <- max(Italy$Date_reported)
Italy_Cases <- Italy %>%
  select(c(Date_reported, New_cases)) %>%
  filter(New_cases %in% c(fivenum(Italy$New_cases))) %>%
  rename("New" = "New_cases") %>%
  arrange(New)
Italy_Deaths <- Italy %>%
  select(c(Date_reported, New_deaths)) %>%
  filter(New_deaths %in% c(fivenum(Italy$New_deaths))) %>%
  rename("New" = "New_deaths") %>%
  arrange(New)
Italy_Summary <- rbind(Italy_Cases, Italy_Deaths)
Statistics <- c("Minimum", "1st Quantile", "Median", "3rd Quantile", "Maximum",
          "Minimum", "1st Quantile", "1st Quantile", "1st Quantile", "1st Quantile", "1st Quantile", "1st Quantile", "Median", "3rd Quantile", "3rd Quantile", "3rd Quantile", "Maximum")
Italy_Summary <- cbind(Italy_Summary[,1], Statistics, Italy_Summary[,2])

Italy_Summary %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(title = "Summary of Daily New Cases & Deaths",
             subtitle = glue::glue("{start_date} to {end_date}")) %>%
    tab_row_group(
    label = "Daily Deaths",
    rows = 6:17
  ) %>%
   tab_row_group(
    label = "Daily Cases",
    rows = 1:5
  ) %>%
 cols_width(
    everything() ~ px(215)
  ) %>%
  cols_align(align = c("center"),
  columns = 2) %>%
  tab_options(heading.background.color = "slategray1", 
              row_group.background.color = "lavender",
              source_notes.background.color = "lightcyan") %>%
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = "Source: WHO Coronavirus (COVID-19) Dashboard"
  ) %>%
  tab_options(row_group.border.bottom.color = "grey")

2021-02-06 3rd Quantile 377
2020-12-04 Maximum 993
Source: WHO Coronavirus (COVID-19) Dashboard

Data story

Do you notice a surge that appears in the giFs in around November 2020? The Coronavirus came so suddenly that Italians didnt realize how serious the problem was, causing the collapse of a previously stable health care system. At that time hospitals couldnt accept any more patients so that people cant get treatment in time which led to a bigger outbreak of COVID-19. However, just look carefully through the summary table! Although the number of confirmed cases has decreased in recent months, it is still a relatively large number. During the same period, the number of deaths decreased significantly, with much fewer deaths in June and July 2021 than at the beginning of the year, reflecting a steady improvement in cure rates. The recovery of the epidemic cannot be achieved without improved national policy controls, a better health systems or the subsequent advent of vaccines! Thats a good omen, isnt it?

Anyway, I wish Italian people, also people all around the world, a good health and a speedy recovery from the COVID-19!
